description: If-then reasoning, contrapositive logic, necessary conclusions from conditional statements, and determining what must be true based on given premises.

concepts.name: Basic If-Then Reasoning
concepts.description: Understanding that 'If A then B' means whenever A is true, B must be true
common_misconceptions: Thinking 'If A then B' means 'If B then A' (converse error)
Assuming A must be true if B is true
question_patterns: If [condition], then [result]. Given [condition], what must be true?
Which conclusion follows from: If [A] then [B]?
example_stems: If it rains, the ground gets wet. It is raining. What must be true?
All dogs are mammals. Spot is a dog. What can we conclude?

concepts.name: Contrapositive Reasoning
concepts.description: Understanding that 'If A then B' is logically equivalent to 'If not B then not A'
common_misconceptions: Thinking 'If not A then not B' is valid (inverse error)
Not recognizing the contrapositive as logically equivalent
question_patterns: If [A] then [B]. [Not B] is true. What must be true?
Which statement is logically equivalent to: If [A] then [B]?
example_stems: If a student passes, they studied. Tom did not study. What can we conclude?
All squares are rectangles. This shape is not a rectangle. What follows?

concepts.name: Chain of Conditional Reasoning
concepts.description: Linking multiple conditional statements: If A then B, If B then C, therefore If A then C
question_patterns: If [A] then [B]. If [B] then [C]. Given [A], what must be true?
Following the chain of rules, what conclusion can be drawn?
example_stems: If it's Monday, I go to school. If I go to school, I take the bus. It's Monday. What follows?
All cats are mammals. All mammals are warm-blooded. Whiskers is a cat. What must be true?

concepts.name: Necessary vs Sufficient Conditions
concepts.description: Distinguishing between conditions that are required (necessary) and conditions that guarantee a result (sufficient)
common_misconceptions: Not understanding 'only if' as stating necessity
question_patterns: What is a necessary condition for [outcome]?
example_stems: You can vote only if you are 18 or older. Sam is 18. Can Sam vote?
Being a square is sufficient for being a rectangle. Is it necessary?

concepts.name: Logical Equivalence
concepts.description: Identifying statements that have the same truth value in all situations
question_patterns: Which statement means the same as: [statement]?
Which of the following is logically equivalent?
example_stems: Which statement is equivalent to 'Not all birds can fly'?
If it's not raining, I walk. Which statement means the same?

concepts.name: Reasoning from Multiple Premises
concepts.description: Drawing conclusions when given multiple conditional statements that must all be considered
common_misconceptions: Only using some premises and ignoring others
Drawing conclusions that don't follow from all premises
Assuming more than what is stated
question_patterns: Given all of the following, what must be true?
Based on these rules, what can we conclude?
example_stems: All A are B. All B are C. Some C are D. What must be true about A?
If it's sunny, we go to the beach. If it's Saturday, we have time. It's a sunny Saturday. What follows?
